BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs formed by the sometimes moderate wind can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and on wind-loaded slopes. In particular on very steep slopes medium-sized to large dry avalanches are possible.
The soft wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack. At elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low altitude only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. They are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Restraint is advisable on this first sunny day after a long period of poor weather.
The new snow-covered wind slabs of last week remain in some cases prone to triggering above approximately 2000 m. They can be released by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack here.
As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from northeasterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form in the course of the day in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude. Fresh wind slabs can be released easily.
As a consequence of solar radiation individual avalanches are possible. Especially in extremely steep terrain small and medium sized dry avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2000 m.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly.
The old snowpack is hard. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. Restraint is advisable on this first sunny day after a long period of poor weather.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was moderate to strong at times. In the last few days sometimes deep wind slabs formed in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2200 m. Dry avalanches can additionally in some places be released in near-surface layers in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
In the regions with a lot of snow medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Single skiers can release avalanches easily, including large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in the regions with a lot of snow small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind. These can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases or triggered naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 40 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last five days.
In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual strengthening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Single skiers can release avalanches easily, including large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls a considerable avalanche danger will persist in some regions. In particular at the base of rock walls and on very steep sunny slopes individual mostly small snow slides are possible as a consequence of solar radiation. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular on steep shady slopes, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. In high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are present in all aspects.

Individual dry loose snow avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong northeasterly wind, wind slabs will form in the afternoon. The fresh and older wind slabs are lying on soft layers.

The wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places. The new snow of last week is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind. These can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases or triggered naturally.
The wind slabs have formed adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects and generally at elevated altitudes. They are to be bypassed in particular in very steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 40 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last five days.
In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In the last few days wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of wind, clearly visible wind slabs formed. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist small and medium sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow has fallen since Friday. Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry avalanches are possible. The wind slabs are mostly shallow but can be released in isolated cases.
These avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last five days above approximately 1500 m.
Only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. Especially on wind-loaded slopes and on steep slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular in the Prealps below approximately 2000 m. Below approximately 1400 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In the last few days wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of wind, clearly visible wind slabs formed. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist small and medium sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular on steep shady slopes, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. In high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are present in all aspects.

Individual dry loose snow avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong northeasterly wind, wind slabs will form in the afternoon. The fresh and older wind slabs are lying on soft layers.

The wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places above the tree line. The new snow of last week is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from easterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude. They will be deposited on soft layers. Fresh wind slabs can be released easily.
In addition the old wind slabs are prone to triggering in isolated cases. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, especially on very steep slopes. They are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 cm of snow, and up to 20 cm in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches are not to be expected. Wind slabs require caution. In addition the small wind slabs of the last few days in gullies and bowls in all aspects and generally in the high Alpine regions are prone to triggering in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular in the northeast some new snow above approximately 1500 m. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be quite favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The conditions are mostly favourable.
